ygData.subject: Re: New Paper on the Problem with Objectives in Evolution
ygData.msgSnippet: Daniel, perhaps it will help to clarify the point if i try to frame it more directly: First, there are many interesting artifacts in a search space.  In

From: "Ken" <kstanley@...>
Subject: Re: New Paper on the Problem with Objectives in Evolution
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=54567749; y=JRY2QH-3M2NKfcn6ra8cV7fAxqyBgABXaokGW48vYXFRvM1jwMth
X-Yahoo-Profile: kenstanley01



Daniel, perhaps it will help to clarify the point if i try to frame it mo=
re directly:

First, there are many interesting artifacts in a search space=
.  In Picbreeder, some of these include the skull, the car, the butterfly, =
etc.

Second, I assume that all would agree that we would like to discover =
such artifacts if we can.  Not necessarily those particular artifacts, but =
ones like them.

Third, the evidence in the paper supports the fact that ob=
jective-based search has almost no hope of discovering any such artifacts -=
 not just the ones that have been discovered by Picbreeder - but anything e=
ven like them.

Yet while in the past, say 5 years ago, we would have said =
that we simply do not know how to discover such artifacts (a fact which the=
 paper plays on), we can no longer say that because they *have* been discov=
ered on Picbreeder, and consistently.  Thus we see that a whole class of in=
teresting discoveries are within reach yet only if we abandon objective-bas=
ed search.

Now you may say that the issue boils down to a distinction betw=
een "objectively and subjectively interesting" but I think that distinction=
 is misleading.  Ultimately *any* objective at which we aim is subjectively=
 interesting.  You cite traveling salesman as objectively interesting, but =
ultimately whether or not we care about traveling salesman is just as subje=
ctive as whether we care about the Skull.  We cannot separate these types o=
f achievements so easily because some of the artifacts discovered through n=
on-objective search will in fact be direct solutions to "objective" problem=
s, such as the biped walker evolved through novelty search.  So I think the=
 desire to "objectify" science ultimately is distracting us from our princi=
ple concern, which is to discover things we care about in the search space,=
 both for pleasure and for practical or scientific purposes.

The concern i=
s that there are analogous discoveries to the Skull in the space of neuroco=
ntrollers.  And they will be just as impossible to reach through objective =
search.  That should be ringing alarm bells, because we want to find those =
"Skulls" of control; they are the true needles in the haystack.

What is co=
ming into focus for me is that I think we are facing a stark and previously=
 unrecognized trade-off:

-We have shown convincingly as a community that w=
e can find nice solutions to medium-range objective problems like pole-bala=
ncing or Keepaway soccer through objective search.  These problems are anal=
ogous to the Simple and Crescent patterns in the paper: not so interesting,=
 but solved reliably.  Thus one choice is to continue to play in the playgr=
ound of mediocre problems where we get exactly what we ask for and nothing =
more or less.

-On the other hand, it appears that many interesting things =
are possible to discover that are far beyond Simple and Crescent, such as t=
he Skull and Butterfly.  These are real discoveries that are consistently s=
urprising when they happen.  However, we can only discover such artifacts i=
f we submit to the principle that we may *not* define a priori what we expe=
ct to find.  In other words, search is able to discover wonderful things, b=
ut only if you stop trying to tell search what it is supposed to find.  (e.=
g. No one told nature that it was supposed to find human brains.)

Thus we =
face a trade-off:  We can find anything we want as long as it is modest, or=
, we can find things well beyond modest as long as we do not try to control=
 what those things are from the start.  Evidence is accumulating that this =
trade-off is real, and the paper supports that trend.  It is not proof, but=
 it is evidence, and it is a major concern for a field focused almost exclu=
sively on objectively-driven discovery.

You finally had some concerns with=
 disentangling the "interactive" and
"objective-driven" variables.  That is=
 a indeed a valid concern and they could be better disentangled than in the=
 paper.  However, unless you believe that humans actually can reach these p=
articular images as objectives better than computers (for which there is no=
 evidence and plenty of counter-evidence), then this concern exists in prin=
ciple but is unlikely in practice.

For example, here is the counter-eviden=
ce: You would have to argue that somehow the user who evolved the "dish" 

=
http://picbreeder.org/search/showgenome.php?sid=3D541

actually intended it=
 to evolve into a skull, which is a far-fetched hypothesis.  Or that the us=
er who evolved the alien

http://picbreeder.org/search/showgenome.php?sid=
=3D375

was actually thinking ahead to discovering a car.  

That is, becau=
se we know the intermediate stepping stones in dozens or hundreds of cases =
that were published by users who had no way to know what ultimately would b=
e evolved from their own stepping stones, it would be fantastical to assert=
 that those users knew where the search was ultimately going to go.  It is =
clear from Picbreeder that those who lay the stepping stones have no idea w=
here those stepping stones may lead.  Of course, this idea should not be su=
rprising: It's always been the story of innovation.  Who knows where any gr=
eat discovery might lead?  

ken

ohy <danielr2e@...> wrote:
>
> Ken,
> 
> My response consists primarily of =
clarifying questions, depending on the
> answer I may or may not go back on=
 the offensive :)
> 
> On Sat, Apr 2, 2011 at 5:17 PM, Ken <kstanley@...> w=
rote:
> 
> >
> >
> > Daniel, I appreciate very much you sharing your though=
ts. We were hoping to
> > provoke just such discussion with this paper and =
your questions highlight
> > important issues. Let me try to respond below.=
..
> >
> >
> > > -----Original Message-----
> > > From: Kenneth Stanley [ma=
ilto:kstanley@...]
> > > Sent: Saturday, April 02, 2011 2:57 AM
> > > To: '=
Kenneth Stanley'
> > > Subject: todelete2
> > >
> > > Ken,
> > >
> > > Firs=
t off, I'll say that what I take as the central point, that EAs can
> > > m=
iss
> > > critical intermediate objectives because they are awkwardly place=
d on the
> > > fitness landscape, is a good one. However, I have some conce=
rns about the
> > > experimental design in this paper:
> > >
> > > (1) You =
appear to be manipulating two variables at once. (a) whether the
> > > EA
>=
 > > has an objective and (b) whether there is a human in the loop. Surely =
you
> > > have to pick only one at a time and control for everything else, =
right?
> > >
> >
> > It's only a problem if you believe that somehow a huma=
n would do better at
> > evolving to these objectives, which of course huma=
ns would not. Good luck to
> > anyone who wants to re-evolve the skull from=
 scratch again. It will never
> > happen. Nor will anyone evolve any reason=
ably complex *preconceived* picture
> > from scratch no matter where it cam=
e from, whether once evolved in the past
> > or not.
> >
> 
> 
> Ok, intere=
sting.  I think I have misjudged the scope of the experiment.  I
> assumed =
you were trying to *prove* something significant about the fact that
> GAs =
can't evolve the solutions produced in picbreeder.  This was the basis
> fo=
r my primary objection (3).  But you admit that the IGA won't evolve those
=
> specific images either, with or without an objective.  Instead, you're ju=
st
> trying to persuade the reader of a suspicion based on just how bad the=

> performance is.  So really this paper would fall more under the category=
 of
> "evidence-based musings", is that fair?
> 
> 
> 
> >
> > On the other=
 hand if you want to see non-objective search without a human
> > in the lo=
op, that's what we've been doing with novelty search, so there is
> > plent=
y of literature on that combination at this point. You can find a lot
> > h=
ere:
> >
> > http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/noveltysearch/userspage/
> >
> 
> >
> =
> Let me suggest to you or anyone who remains a skeptic (which is perfectly=

> > reasonable) to check out my talk on the topic (recorded in video), whi=
ch
> > lays out the ideas much more broadly. It's only 70 minutes and I thi=
nk you
> > will find it worth the time to see how I try to defend this
> > =
counter-intuitive position, if nothing else to stimulate some thinking even=

> > if you still feel skeptical:
> >
> > http://www.infoq.com/presentation=
s/Searching-Without-Objectives
> >
> 
> 
> I haven't seen your talk on nove=
lty search, I'll take a look at this.
> 
> 
> 
> >
> > > (2) Furthermore, i=
f it's IGA v. GA and 'interestingness' is the
> > evaluation
> > > criteria=
, that ain't a fair fight. Why should I believe there is more to
> > > it
>=
 > > than that?
> > >
> >
> > But interestingness wasn't the evaluation cri=
teria. This paper played by
> > the traditional ground rules to whose defen=
se you are now jumping. The
> > objective was definitively the skull (or th=
e butterfly, or the eye..), not
> > "interestingness." The fact that the re=
sults come out so abysmally and leave
> > you wanting to argue about intere=
stingness just shows how unreasonable
> > peddling these objectives as mean=
ingful benchmarks can be. That's the whole
> > point - the paper is a play =
on the traditional algorithmic evaluation scheme
> > that leaves the reader=
 squirming, as it should.
> >
> > In fact, if you really think that IGA vs.=
 GA isn't a "fair fight" when we
> > are aiming for interestingness, then y=
ou are in part in agreement (though
> > inadvertently) with the spirit of o=
ur message. That is, if you are really
> > convinced that IGA is so far sup=
erior to GAs at doing something interesting
> > that it isn't even fair to =
contrast them, then unless we are somehow
> > intentionally trying to avoid=
 evolving anything interesting, what are we
> > doing wasting our time with=
 objective GAs? Does it not highlight a central
> > paradox in our position=
 that we might actually care more about being "fair"
> > than being "intere=
sting?" Why are we even running these algorithms?
> >
> 
> 
> There's a dif=
ference between objectively and subjectively interesting.  The
> former inc=
ludes the conventional optimization domains (e.g. travelling
> salesmen) an=
d the latter include things like evolutionary art and music.  Is
> this bra=
nch of your research only concerned with the latter type of problem
> (at l=
east currently)?
> 
> 
> 
> >
> >
> > > (3) How do we know that intermediat=
e objectives are in any way
> > significant
> > > to discovering interestin=
g pictures in Picbreeder? I have a sneaking
> > > suspicion that totally ra=
ndom search, followed by focused objective based
> > > search when somethin=
g 'pops' might be just as effective, and that the
> > > 'intermediate objec=
tives', while certainly necessary to find a particular
> > > image, are not=
 very helpful in general to finding interesting images. If
> > > so, this i=
s no chink in the armor of objective based search. I suppose
> > > without =
intermediate objectives there can be no exaptation, but does that
> > > mat=
ter? What percentage of evolved features in biological organisms have
> > >=
 any exaptation at all in their history?
> > >
> >
> > When you say the ran=
dom search followed by objective-based search would be
> > "just as effecti=
ve," I don't really understand: just as effective at what?
> > At doing som=
ething "interesting?" At achieving a specific objective? Surely
> > you don=
't believe that random search will produce images as interesting as
> > Pic=
breeder? The stepping stones (i.e. intermediate objectives) in Picbreeder
>=
 > are in effect fundamental discoveries of important regularities that are=

> > later elaborated. For example, this simple face-like stepping stone le=
ads to
> > a whole family of subsequent faces:
> >
> > http://picbreeder.or=
g/search/showgenome.php?sid=3D542
> >
> > Here you can get a family-tree ex=
pansion from that individual:
> > http://picbreeder.org/search/familytree.p=
hp?sid=3D542
> >
> > If you are willing to skip bridges like that because t=
hey are intermediate,
> > you would never find any of the treasures on the =
other side of the bridge.
> > If you look back in the lineages of almost an=
y interesting image on the site
> > you will find a similar story wherein f=
undamental regularities that were
> > later exploited were first discovered=
 in a different context.
> >
> 
> 
> This point seems to beg for some contr=
ols for bias.  Would we not expect
> users to choose interesting pictures t=
o start from most often?  And then
> shouldn't we be unsurprised when most =
of the new interesting images have
> these in their lineages?  And shouldn'=
t we be least surprised of all that
> they share fundamental regularities w=
ith these ancestors?
> 
> Complicating this even further is the fact that s=
mall genotypic changes in
> picbreeder genomes create significant divergenc=
e in phenotype (correct me if
> I'm wrong).  So a varied set of interesting=
 pictures can readily proliferate
> a short evolutionary distance away from=
 a single ancestor, which exaggerates
> the representation of interesting p=
ictures of the type you describe.
> 
> 
> 
> >
> >
> > Just compare figure =
6 and figure 7 in the paper to see how horrible it is
> > to start from a r=
andom place and then lock in on an objective (figure 7). It
> > takes 29,00=
0 generations to do the same thing it took 12 to do better.
> >
> 
> >
> > =
> (4) Finally - and this is the big one - one of the deadly sins of Science=

> > > is
> > > claiming a result as the objective a posteriori, a point wh=
ich eludes
> > even
> > > some very famous scientists. It's what allows pub=
lications like this,
> > > which
> > > 'prove' psychic phenomena by mining =
data for 'statistically significant'
> > > results. The problem is, a resul=
t isn't significant unless you were
> > > specifically attempting to confir=
m it when the experiment was designed
> > > (i.e.
> > > always follow up ex=
ploratory experiment with a confirmatory experiment!).
> > > I
> > > hearti=
ly endorse exploring for/marvelling at results you weren't
> > initially
> =
> > looking for, but one should never use such results as the basis for any=

> > > sort
> > > of comparison. In the case of the eye experiment, who car=
es if the GA
> > > couldn't evolve the eye? The IGA can't either, and the f=
act that it
> > > already
> > > did is immaterial! I could be persuaded tha=
t the IGA is better at
> > evolving
> > > interesting images, but I do not =
believe it's any better at evolving the
> > > 'eye' (or 'dolphin', or 'appl=
e'). In fact, I would bet that's it's worse
> > > at
> > > evolving those s=
pecific images, intermediate objectives notwithstanding.
> > >
> >
> > Shou=
ld we really believe your statement? : "I heartily endorse exploring
> > fo=
r/marvelling at results you weren't initially looking for, but one should
>=
 > never use such results as the basis for any sort of comparison."
> >
> >=
 Is not our entire infatuation with evolution, the very reason we choose to=

> > explore it as an algorithm, for the very reason that you say we should=
 never
> > use such comparisons? After all, natural evolution is just such =
a gallery of
> > "results you weren't initially looking for" yet it is the =
core inspiration
> > for all our hopes and dreams for the field and the exa=
mple against which
> > many of us compare our algorithms. Thus I strongly d=
isagree with the
> > principle you want to impose that marvels attained wit=
hout explicit a priori
> > intent are outside of the realm of scientific in=
terest.
> >
> 
> 
> No, not out of the realm of scientific interest!  Just =
out of the realm of
> naive scientific experimentation (unless, as I suspec=
t is the case here, you
> are reporting the results because they are *inter=
esting*, not because they
> prove anything).  Note that I am not using 'nai=
ve' perjoratively, just
> pointing out that this problem that you've decide=
d to tackle will require
> exceedingly clever experimental design if you wa=
nt to prove something.
> 
> 
> 
> 
> > On the contrary, in fact the point o=
f the paper is that our mistake is
> > precisely that we have been misled b=
y such a restrictive and dogmatic
> > doctrine. It is time that we did begi=
n to contemplate the marvel of what is
> > discovered a posteriori. Asking =
why such amazing discoveries as human beings
> > happens in nature is nothi=
ng like entertaining psychic phenomena.
> >
> 
> 
> Just as an aside, I was=
 not suggesting that it was.  The fact that the paper
> I cited was about '=
psi' was incidental, it was just the most
> fresh-in-my-mind example of a m=
istake I thought you were making.
> 
> 
> 
> >
> > Imagine if we had left o=
ut the part about Picbreeder and simply run some
> > experiments to see if =
NEAT can evolve a set of pictures. After it failed
> > miserably every time=
, following the traditional interpretation, we would
> > conclude that NEAT=
 cannot evolve such pictures, or even pictures *like*
> > them. The fact th=
at Picbreeder did evolve many such pictures is thus
> > relevant and scient=
ifically interesting; it shows why the traditional
> > implications we draw=
 from such "failures" are far too expansive.
> >
> > You say that you could=
 be persuaded that the IGA is better at evolving
> > interesting images yet=
 then you say that you don't think it is better at
> > evolving the eye. Ye=
t the whole point is that it is better at evolving
> > interesting images. =
Beware of missing the forest for the trees: It is not
> > important whether=
 the IGA is good at evolving the eye (or dolphin, or
> > apple); it is impo=
rtant that it is good at evolving images *like* those.
> > There is no othe=
r algorithm on Earth that can do that. That is, there is no
> > other appro=
ach that we know of that could get NEAT to actually encode images
> > *like=
* cars and butterflies in a CPPN. That fact should be startling to us,
> > =
not dismissed as a mere curiosity.
> >
> 
> 
> 
> Ok, I mostly agree with t=
his, but I must reiterate my discomfort with the
> fact that the experiment=
 does not disentangle the "interactive" and
> "objective-driven" variables.=
  Without doing so, how are we to know what is
> really doing the heavy lif=
ting of creating these interesting pictures?
> 
> 
> 
> 
> >
> >
> > > Anyw=
ay, though I have a lot of doubts about this particular paper, I
> > really=

> > > appreciate these sorts of research directions. Keep up the good work=
!
> > >
> >
> > Sure, I understand. A good hard defense of the status quo i=
s healthy to
> > ensure that no one gets away with taking unjustifiable pot=
shots :) Yet at
> > the same time, questioning the status quo is sometimes =
important if progress
> > is to be made.
> >
> 
> 
> Agreed.
